Expectation1: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation1: Roads are dry with light traffic and normal speed limits
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: It is time for the daily morning prayer service in the main chapel, as scheduled in the convent's regular order of the day.
Story: I glanced at the dashboard clock as I pulled up to a red light, my taxi humming quietly beneath me. The roads were clear, the morning sun just beginning to warm the city. I had one more passenger to drop off before I could return to the convent. My hands tightened on the steering wheel. The chapel bell would ring in ten minutes, calling all the sisters to morning prayer. As a nun, I was expected to be present, kneeling in the pews, joining my sisters in devotion. But as a taxi driver, I was responsible for my passenger’s safety, for obeying every traffic law, for not rushing or cutting corners. The urge to speed up, to shave off a few minutes, gnawed at me. I could make it if I pushed the limits, but that would mean risking a ticket—or worse, an accident. My heart pounded with the weight of both vows: to serve faithfully in the world, and to serve faithfully in the chapel. The light turned green, and I hesitated, torn between the road ahead and the sanctuary waiting for me.
